description:
Arenibacter troitsensis is a species of bacteria that was first isolated from coastal sand samples collected near the town of Troitsk, Russia. It is a Gram-negative, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium that belongs to the phylum Bacteroidetes.

The cells of Arenibacter troitsensis are rod-shaped and motile, with a size range of 0.5-0.8 μm in width and 1.5-3.0 μm in length. The bacterium is capable of growing at temperatures between 10°C and 37°C, with an optimal growth temperature of 25-30°C.

Arenibacter troitsensis is able to utilize a variety of carbohydrates, including glucose, sucrose, and maltose, as carbon and energy sources. It can also hydrolyze starch and casein, indicating its ability to produce extracellular enzymes.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that Arenibacter troitsensis is closely related to other members of the genus Arenibacter, which are commonly found in marine and coastal environments.

The ecological role and potential applications of Arenibacter troitsensis are still under investigation, but its ability to thrive in sandy coastal habitats and its metabolic versatility suggest that it may play a role in nutrient cycling and organic matter decomposition in these environments.
